subject: Re: [junit] JUnit 4 restructuring
msgSnippet: ... Neither of these is entirely the question that I thought was on the table, which was given the choice between releasing software with all possible methods
messageBody:
Elliotte Harold wrote:

> Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:
>
> > Between code that I cannot reuse at all and code that I can reuse
> but that
> > might break in the future, I will take my chances with the latter
> any day.
>
> Given the choice between a class I can safely reuse in obvious way, and
> a class that requires me to read pages of half-thought-out documentation
> and then inspect the source code to try and figure out what's really
> going on because Java programmers almost never bother to document their
> pre and post-conditions, I will choose the former any day.

Neither of these is entirely the question that I thought was on the
table, which was given the choice between releasing software with all
possible methods made private, and releasing with all possible methods
made protected, or something in between.

My experience is that it is best to allow a gradient to your users and
extenders. There should be public, javadoc'ed, committed, released API,
but there should also be some beta API's, protected methods without
commitment, public implementation classes in packages marked internal.
Is it necessary that the presence of the latter should interfere at all
with the comprehensibility or quality of the former?

David Saff
